body:
Hey, thanks for reporting this, and for providing a reproducible.

Fixed on main, if you want to take a swing at it. 

Will release it later today as well.

Thanks for the quick fix! üéâ 

I just tested with current `main` and I can confirm that it works now üíØ.

issue.title: build command ignores --single-target
issue.body:
### What happened?

**What happened**
I'm wanting to only build one target that doesn't get published. To do this, I'm using the following

```
GOOS=linux GOARCH=amd64 goreleaser build --clean --snapshot --single-target
```

My understanding is that this should clean out the dist folder and then build a single binary for linux amd64 without using a git tag. Instead, it's still building a binary for all platforms

```
  ‚Ä¢ starting build...
  ‚Ä¢ loading                                          path=.goreleaser.yaml
  ‚Ä¢ building only for linux/amd64                    reason=single target is enabled
  ‚Ä¢ skipping validate...
  ‚Ä¢ loading environment variables
  ‚Ä¢ getting and validating git state
    ‚Ä¢ ignoring errors because this is a snapshot     error=git doesn't contain any tags. Either add a tag or use --snapshot
    ‚Ä¢ git state                                      commit=d4b5de7509de37b868a8051e090fed22e5d1cbcf branch=CI current_tag=v0.0.0 previous_tag=<unknown> dirty=false
    ‚Ä¢ pipe skipped                                   reason=disabled during snapshot mode
  ‚Ä¢ parsing tag
  ‚Ä¢ setting defaults
  ‚Ä¢ snapshotting
    ‚Ä¢ building snapshot...                           version=0.0.0-d4b5de7
  ‚Ä¢ checking distribution directory
    ‚Ä¢ cleaning dist
  ‚Ä¢ loading go mod information
  ‚Ä¢ build prerequisites
  ‚Ä¢ writing effective config file
    ‚Ä¢ writing                                        config=dist/config.yaml
  ‚Ä¢ building binaries
    ‚Ä¢ building                                       binary=dist/windows_386/binary.exe
    ‚Ä¢ building                                       binary=dist/linux_amd64_v1/binary
    ‚Ä¢ building                                       binary=dist/linux_386/binary
    ‚Ä¢ building                                       binary=dist/linux_arm64/binary
    ‚Ä¢ building                                       binary=dist/darwin_amd64_v1/binary
    ‚Ä¢ building                                       binary=dist/darwin_arm64/binary
    ‚Ä¢ building                                       binary=dist/windows_arm64/binary.exe
    ‚Ä¢ building                                       binary=dist/windows_amd64_v1/binary.exe
```

**What I expected to happen**
Only the binary for linux amd64 should've been built

### How can we reproduce this?

I'm running ubuntu 22.04 and using goreleaser from snap. I use the following command

```
GOOS=linux GOARCH=amd64 goreleaser build --clean --snapshot --single-target
```

Ultimately, this will be running an ubuntu 22.04 image in CI which downloads goreleaser as part of a goreleaser action. I'm getting the same behavior in CI.

### goreleaser version

```bash
1.22.0

I just checked in CI and 1.21.2 works as expected
```


### GoReleaser Check

- [X] goreleaser check shows no errors

### Search

- [X] I did search for other open and closed issues before opening this

### Supporter

- [ ] I am a [sponsor](https://github.com/sponsors/caarlos0/) or a [Pro](https://goreleaser.com/pro) customer

### Code of Conduct

- [X] I agree to follow this project's Code of Conduct

### Additional context

_No response_

body:
@till a release with this fix (https://github.com/goreleaser/goreleaser/releases/tag/v1.22.1) is already out for two weeks now.
I can confirm it has been working fine for us since.

We got this error with `1.22.1`:

```
 /opt/hostedtoolcache/goreleaser-action/1.22.1/x64/goreleaser build --snapshot --rm-dist --single-target
  ‚Ä¢ starting build...
  ‚Ä¢ loading                                          path=.goreleaser.yaml
  ‚Ä¢ DEPRECATED: --rm-dist was deprecated in favor of --clean, check https://goreleaser.com/deprecations#-rm-dist for more details
  ‚Ä¢ building only for linux/amd64                    reason=single target is enabled
  ‚®Ø build failed after 0s                    error=no builds matching --single-target linux/amd64
Error: The process '/opt/hostedtoolcache/goreleaser-action/1.22.1/x64/goreleaser' failed with exit code 1
```

But it looks like a different error, didn't look close enough the first time. But not sure where this came from, just started happening.

issue.title: single-target cannot find build
issue.body:
We got this error with `1.22.1`:

```
 /opt/hostedtoolcache/goreleaser-action/1.22.1/x64/goreleaser build --snapshot --rm-dist --single-target
  ‚Ä¢ starting build...
  ‚Ä¢ loading                                          path=.goreleaser.yaml
  ‚Ä¢ DEPRECATED: --rm-dist was deprecated in favor of --clean, check https://goreleaser.com/deprecations#-rm-dist for more details
  ‚Ä¢ building only for linux/amd64                    reason=single target is enabled
  ‚®Ø build failed after 0s                    error=no builds matching --single-target linux/amd64
Error: The process '/opt/hostedtoolcache/goreleaser-action/1.22.1/x64/goreleaser' failed with exit code 1
```

_Originally posted by @till in https://github.com/goreleaser/goreleaser/issues/4411#issuecomment-1821034379_

My goreleaser config is very simple:


```yaml
before:
  hooks:
    - go mod tidy
builds:
  - env:
      - CGO_ENABLED=0
    ldflags:
      -  -s -w -X main.Version={{.Version}}
    main: ./cmd/foo
    goos:
      - linux
      - windows
      - darwin
archives:
  - name_template: >-
      {{ .ProjectName }}_
      {{- title .Os }}_
      {{- if eq .Arch "darwin" }}Darwin
      {{- else if eq .Arch "linux" }}Linux
      {{- else if eq .Arch "386" }}i386
      {{- else if eq .Arch "amd64" }}x86_64
      {{- else }}{{ .Arch }}{{ end }}
    wrap_in_directory: true
    format_overrides:
      - goos: windows
        format: zip
    files: # don't add README/LICENSE files
      - none*
```

There's more, but it's docker and docker manifests.

My guess is, that the `--single-target` cannot match because we are not explicitly defining amd64, arm64 (aka `goarch`), etc. in the `builds:`?

At least, that's my guess. We downgraded the build on that one project for the time being. We usually just build `amd64` and `--single-target` works there, but this project _needs_ everything.
